caseTitle: THE REPUBLIC v KEVIN DINSDALE GORMAN
summary: The case of THE REPUBLIC v KEVIN DINSDALE GORMAN, heard by the Supreme Court of Ghana in 2004, appears to involve a criminal appeal concerning the conviction and/or sentencing of Kevin Dinsdale Gorman. While the full text is unavailable due to file corruption, the case likely addressed key principles of criminal law, including the burden of proof, fairness of trial, and constitutional protections for the accused. As an appellate decision, it may have clarified standards for evidentiary sufficiency or procedural compliance in criminal proceedings within Ghana's legal system.
citations: SUPREME COURT/2004A/THE REPUBLIC v KEVIN DINSDALE GORMAN
rationaleHighlights: Standard of proof in criminal cases is beyond reasonable doubt
Importance of adherence to procedural fairness
Role of appellate courts in reviewing trial court errors
